PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is needed to undertake sector 
preparatory work and define the scope of the ensuing project.   
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
2.  The PPTA has been structured in two phases. Phase 1 has been specifically conceived 
to (i) conduct economic and sector analyses, road map and policy framework preparation for 
cluster development in Bangalore Metropolitan Region, and (ii) prepare prefeasibility studies for 
priority clusters (6-8) for assistance and an investment program.1 Phase 2 will conduct detailed 
feasibility studies for two clusters to be financed under Tranche 1, structure investments for 
public  and  public-private  partnership  financing,  prepare  multitranche  financing  facility 
frameworks (safeguards and otherwise) and prepare a package for financing by ADB (public 
and/or private sectors) and other cofinanciers (which may include syndication from private 
sector and/or joint or parallel financing from other international financing institutions and/or 
development partners). The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table A4.1.

3.  To stimulate Bangalore’s growth potential, the PPTA proposes to blend a multisectoral 
comprehensive  and  tested  analytical framework for  competitiveness  and  the  application of 
demand driven approaches that build on partnerships between the private sector and local 
government. To promote multi-stakeholder ownership, the PPTA proposes to apply a highly 
participatory approach from planning to design stages. This is expected to lead to stronger 
public-private partnerships, generate investors’ confidence, and in parallel leverage, private 
sector  financing.  In  addition,  the  PPTA  seeks  to  generate  endogenous  and  exogenous 
knowledge and proposes to share through publications and workshops.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
4.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,300,000 equivalent, which will be financed on a grant 
basis through ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff; office space; surveys, engineering 
and other studies previously conducted; and other in-kind contributions.2

D.  Consulting Services 
 
5.  A firm (or consortium of firms) with multi- cross-sectoral experience will be engaged to 
undertake the necessary studies for this TA. This assignment will require four international 
experts  for  a  total  of  18  person-months,  and  an  estimated  68  person-months  of  national 
expertise (13 consultants). The consulting firm will be engaged following the quality- and cost- 
based selection method, with a quality-cost ratio of 90:10 (due to the high complexity of the 
assignment and the impact of the expected outputs), using full technical proposal procedures. 
Given the specialized nature of the TA, additional consultants may need to be engaged to 
supplement expertise (up to 15 person-months). Procurement of all consultancy services used 
under  the  PPTA  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of

6.  Based on the structure of the TA, the consultants will be responsible for the following: 
Phase 1 will prepare a city competitiveness assessment and a road map or sector strategy for 
the multitranche financing facility to guide the overall investment, including (i) the development 
of strategic directions for the sector, service, and/or industry; (ii) quantitative analysis of the 
sectors/industries  contribution  to  growth,  poverty  reduction,  gender  and  development,  and 
inclusiveness (or the extent to which it is a binding constraint); and (iii) the list of success factors 
for better performance. Using appropriate tools and processes (city economic development 
analysis, prospects and strategic planning),  Phase 1 team will prepare and deliver (i) the 
economic  profile,  (ii)  an  economic  development  perspective  report,  (iii)  the  economic 
development plan for City Cluster Development, (iv) prefeasibility studies for (6-8 clusters) in 
Bangalore Metropolitan Region, and (v) the associated detailed investment program.  
 
7.  In addition to objectives set forth in para. 2 above, during Phase 2, the consultants will 
prepare (i) draft business plans for the medium-term and short-term development for the two 
clusters  selected  for  support  under  Tranche  1;  (ii)  launch  a  program  of  activities  for  the 
operationalization of cluster network partnerships supporting the development of two clusters 
selected under Tranche 1; (iii) prepare a feasibility study for a marketable inter-sectoral project 
for Tranche 1 clusters (this should have the potential to attract ADB, government, and industry 
funding support); and (iv) project structuring options.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  The TA will be implemented over a 16-month period starting in late October 2013. 
KUIDFC will be the nodal agency responsible for overall coordination (with government and 
private  sector  representatives)  and  implementation  of  the  PPTA.  KUIDFC  will  host  the 
consultancy  team,  providing  office  accommodation  and  assisting  access  to  data  and 
information.  Bangalore  Metropolitan  Region  Development  Authority  will  be  responsible  for 
implementing planning activities. Responsible for KUIDFC and Bangalore Metropolitan Region 
Development Authority, the Urban Development Department will oversee the execution of the 
program.  A  high  level  steering  committee,  chaired  by  Chief  Secretary  and  comprising 
representatives  from  all  concerned  departments  will  be  charged  with  leading  policy  and 
investment decisions. An in-charge project director will be assigned to the project on a full-time 
basis  from  the  stage  of  TA  implementation  for  guiding  and  directing  the  preparation  and 
development of studies, prefeasibility and feasibility assessments, and securing that advance 
contracting is timely initiated by the Government.  
 
9.  The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4. All 
disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with the ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended). Purchase of equipment will be made in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (March 2013, as amended).
